title: how to run autoconf AC_COMPILE_IFELSE
body:
Is there a way to run a config test similar to autoconf's
AC_COMPILE_IFELSE from inside a spack package.py?  That is, I want to
write a short code snippet and ask if the given compiler successfully
compiles (or links) this piece of code.

This came up in the context of intel-tbb where the build failed
because the code assumes that all non-PHI x86's have transactional
memory and I'm running on a machine that doesn't.  It's a simple test
to write C code that generates an asm instruction and try to compile
it.  How do I do that?

I'm guessing the thematic spack way of handling this is with a
variant.  But I consider that unsatisfactory because it pushes all the
work to the end user.  The user has to know what all the tests are,
run them, and then write a long spec for every variant.

A better solution is to have package.py run the test.

An even better solution is to get Intel to fix their config and make
scripts to correctly test for this, but that's another story.

One possibility is to write an actual autoconf configure script, run
all the tests and then write out a spec to feed into spack.  But I was
looking for a more integrated solution.

Thanks,

--Mark

P.S. I did search for configure tests, but I didn't find anything on
point.
